That ' s about the extent of Ronald Pelosi ' s connection to the money in question .

label: REFUTES

The FBI gathers crime stats from departments around the country , and reports a " violent crime " tally based on the number of homicides , sexual assaults , robberies and aggravated assaults .

And we find there essentially is no trend .
But that ' s not necessarily a reliable number .
But that 's not really what the data shows .
Sanfelippo instead claimed the crime rate increased in " all but two Wisconsin cities . "
We ' ll also note that while Sanfelippo referred to cities , the FBI data includes cities , towns and villages , so we ' ll refer to the group as municipalities here .
Amid a discussion of police spending and staffing , the paper used FBI data to say violent crime had risen in Wisconsin from 2008 to 2017 .
That ' s not even close to true .
Sanfelippo acknowledged using the stat incorrectly when questioned by PolitiFact Wisconsin .
Key outlier ignored Sanfelippo - like many other Republicans - is using the FBI data to say violent crime is on the rise across Wisconsin .
Based on that group , the statewide violent crime rate rose from 4.3 to 4.7 per 1,000 residents from 2008 to 2018 .
But Milwaukee accounted for all of that change .
Sanfelippo and the paper point to 2017 data .
Remove Milwaukee and the crime rate across the other 205 municipalities went from 1.77 per 1,000 to 1.74 per 1,000 - virtually unchanged .

Using the 206 municipalities referenced above - those that have data for both 2008 and 2018 and haven ' t changed reporting practices - we find the crime rate rose in 98 municipalities , fell in 88 and was unchanged in 20 .
Here ' s why .
Sanfelippo misquoted the stat he was trying to use while constructing an argument riddled with other data-related problems .
That included three of the 10 largest cities - which you ' ll remember Sanfelippo cited specifically as having a 24 % increase in violent crime .
" I should have picked up on that for as much as I have been talking about crime these last few months . "
The memo said - again , based in part on data the FBI warned against comparing - that violent crime rates increased in all but two of the state ' s 10 largest cities .
Not all data comparable The FBI crime data is difficult to compare year-to-year because it ' s not comprehensive .
It ' s certainly an eye-catching claim .
But the 2018 data , which was available at the time , shows a noteworthy reversal , with the violent crime rate dropping after several years of steady increases .
Addressing these three data issues ( age , comparability and the Milwaukee outlier ) lets us bring the state ' s actual violent crime trend into clearer focus .

Newer data available Asked for evidence supporting his discussion of violent crime , Sanfelippo ' s office pointed us to a policy brief the nonpartisan Wisconsin Policy Forum published in December 2019 .
This was not taken into account in Sanfelippo ' s claim or the memo his office cited as backup .
The reference , which was wrong in both the recorded and written versions of the radio address , came from a script that Sanfelippo said wasn ' t written by him or his office .
Is violent crime up in all but two of the hundreds of cities across Wisconsin ?
Using FBI crime data from 2008 and 2018 and removing the places that changed reporting practices in that span leaves us with 206 municipalities - still a solid sample size .
And state and local officials regularly change their reporting practices , changing definitions or other factors in generating counts .

( We should point out the Wisconsin Department of Justice also gathers crime data that in some cases varies slightly from the FBI , but we ' ll limit our analysis here to the FBI data since that is what is cited by both Sanfelippo and the report he relied on . )
More than two-thirds of the violent crimes in Wisconsin take place in Milwaukee , so in large part the statewide trend is just a reflection of what ' s happening in the state ' s largest city .
We checked it out - and found a case study in how not to use data .
Claim drastically overstated But all of these data mistakes pale in comparison to Sanfelippo ' s dramatic misuse of the memo ' s description .

label: REFUTES
claim: Says U.S. Rep. Dan Lipinski had ""a part in"" undoing a law that used to limit how long trains could idle at crossings."
evidences: Newman is challenging Lipinski to a rematch for Illinois ' 3rd District seat in this year 's Democratic primary .
During a recent podcast interview , Marie Newman used a question about a common transportation problem that rankles drivers to take a jab at her opponent , U.S. Representative Dan Lipinski .

Asked at a canvassing event hosted by Indivisible Chicago what she would say to constituents frustrated by trains blocking their way on the road , Newman said , " it actually used to be a law that idling trains were not allowed .
He clinched a narrow victory over her in 2018 .
And last year , he raised the subject of blocked crossings with the Federal Railroad Administration , highlighting a government study that found average train length had increased 25 % since 2008 .
So we decided to find out whether the eight-term congressman , who entered office in 2005 and currently sits on the House transportation committee , played a role in the law ' s demise .

While that may have been a persuasive argument to some of Newman ' s potential constituents , it was not one she leveraged while attacking her opponent ' s transportation record at the Indivisible Chicago event .
The law was overturned by the Illinois Supreme Court in 2008 after the justices found it incompatible with federal regulations on train speed and air-brake testing .
You could only idle for a very short period of time.That was lifted right around the time that Dan Lipinski came into office and he did have a part in that . "
What ' s more , Lipinski has been vocal in his support for addressing the issue of idling trains .
" While I understand the economic benefits of longer trains , those can not be at the expense of community safety and quality of life for commuters , " Lipinski stated in a July press release .

When we reached out to Newman ' s campaign for an answer , spokesman Ben Hardin confirmed that was the law his candidate was referencing and acknowledged Lipinski had no involvement in the outcome of the case .
" People die because of it .

A judicial - not legislative - decision The federal government places no limit on how long trains can block crossings , but a 1999 Illinois law formerly allowed local municipalities to fine trains that had come to a stop and blocked a crossing for more than 10 minutes unless the train could not be moved for reasons beyond the rail carrier ' s control .
" Right now it stops first responders from getting to where they need to go , so that ' s a big problem , " Newman added .
The bottom line : He wasn ' t involved in any way .
That ' s a lot to pin on Lipinski .

Nevertheless , Hardin contended , Lipinski " has certainly taken part in protecting corporate interests in rail over the best interests of his constituents " in other ways , such as his role in delaying the deadline by which rail companies are required to implement technology designed to automatically slow or stop speeding trains that experts say could save lives .

In 2016 , he wrote a letter to a federal board charged with regulating freight trains asking it to re-examine whether an operator was following an agreement it had made to not block crossings when its purchase of the line received federal approval .
What goes out in terms of toxic emissions into our environment is horrifying . "

Meanwhile , a recent Bloomberg report found railroad companies have successfully sued six other states in addition to Illinois for enacting laws aimed at unsnarling blocked crossings , including neighboring Indiana and Michigan along with Kansas , Oregon and Texas , which are also home to major freight hubs .
That begs the question how Lipinski , a congressman , could have played a part in putting the brakes on a state legal matter settled in court .

That ' s amoral . "
" That ' s wrong .

That means these households have more debt than they have assets .
Specifically , Gross found that the aggregate wealth of the bottom 37 % of households is - $ 44 billion .

When we contacted Bruenig , he said he used the Federal Reserve ' s Summary Extract Public Data , which is offered for researchers to make calculations using statistical software .
In a technical sense , however , tens of millions of Americans join Bloomberg in owning more wealth than the bottom 37 % of households combined , since the bottom 37 % are collectively in the red .
Let ' s walk through the numbers .

Bruenig was more specific than Sanders , writing that by his calculation of Federal Reserve " summary extract public data , " Bloomberg owns nearly six times as much wealth as the bottom 38 % of households .
Bruenig said he sorted all households from those with the least wealth to those with the most wealth .
Then , he determined how many household units this accounted for and found the answer to be 47.8 million .
Bruenig provided us the code that he used with Python , a programming language .
You can then multiply the 47.8 million households by 2.63 ( the average number of people per household ) to come up with 125.7 million people .
That was enough to rank him as the 12th-richest person in the world , according to Forbes .
The facts behind this claim , in many ways , underscore Sanders ' broader message about income inequality .
He then added the wealth of the bottom 38 % of American households to get $ 11.4 billion .

Sen. John Rodgers made national news last week when he introduced a bill that would ban cellphones for Vermonters under the age of 21 .

To drive home his point that the gun control bills are as much a waste of time as his cellphone bill , Rodgers made the claim - on many occasions over the past week - that while people are worrying about the dangers of gun violence in Vermont , they are ignoring something far more dangerous : cellphones .
" Cellphones are far more dangerous than guns are , " Rodgers said in an interview with VTDigger last week .
" No gun has ever been used to radicalize or recruit terrorists , neo-Nazis or fascists .
And the number one killer of teens in the United States is driving while using cellphones . "

In 2015 , motor vehicle crashes were the leading cause of death among " children " 8-15 , " youth " 15-20 , and " young adults " 21-24 , according to the most recent data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration .
He ' s onto something there .
There were approximately 2,500 deaths by suicide among people aged 15-19 , by comparison .
But is he right ?
In emails from his Senate account , Rodgers has doubled down on this point .
It ' s fair to say Rodgers has been falling back on the claim often as he defends himself from cellphone ban blowback .
Of those fatalities , only 23 % - or 63 teen deaths - were caused by cellphones .
" Is it a stunt when I have people around the country talking about the number one killer of teens in America , " he asked one constituent critical of his cellphone ban proposal .
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention report that per mile driven , drivers aged 16 to 19 are three times more likely than drivers 20 and older to be in a fatal crash .

Cellphones are just one factor For Rodgers ' claim to be true , an overwhelming majority of teenage motor vehicle deaths would have to have been caused by cellphone use , so much so that it would still outnumber deaths caused by suicide ( which account for roughly 1,000 fewer teen deaths than car crashes per year ) .
He wrote to another angry emailer : " So you are not concerned with the number one killer of teens in the country .
The most recent data available shows that in 2017 , 271 teenagers died because of distracted driving , according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration .
Further calling Rodgers ' claim into doubt , cellphone use isn ' t even the leading cause of distracted driving .
Driver inexperience takes first place , followed by driving with teen passengers , nighttime driving , and not using seat belts .
It ' s true that the leading cause of teen deaths in the U.S. is motor vehicle accidents .
Distracted driving ( the category that texting while driving falls into ) came in fifth .
However , texting comes nowhere close to topping the CDC ' s list of the leading causes of teen crashes .
That means that even including teenagers too young to drive , Rodgers ' idea that motor vehicle crashes are the number one cause of death among teenagers in the United States still holds true .
But that ' s where the truth in Rodgers ' statement ends .

" I realize that I have framed that poorly in stating several times that the cell phone use it ' s self is the cause when in fact it is a major contributor but not responsible for all accidents , " Rodgers wrote in an email .
Suicide was second on the list .
An important clarification We asked Rodgers where he got his stats .
He quickly walked back his original claim .
You clueless f - - k ! "

that suggests some correlation between the beer and the virus even though there is none .

" First of all , it 's an official document .
" The point of the statute is to prevent people from destroying records in official repositories like the National Archives or in courts , " said Georgetown Law professor Victoria Nourse .
Legal experts told us Pelosi was in the clear .

See Figure 2 on PolitiFact.com The federal statute in question sets a penalty for anyone who " conceals , removes , mutilates , obliterates , or destroys " any government record " filed or deposited with any clerk or officer of any court of the United States , or in any public office , or with any judicial or public officer of the United States . "

See Figure 3 on PolitiFact.com President Donald Trump hands copies of his State of the Union address to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Vice President Mike Pence before delivering it to Congress on Feb. 4 , 2020 , in Washington .
The statute also says that any person with " custody " of a government record can not " willfully and unlawfully " conceal , remove , mutilate , obliterate , falsify or destroy it .
" They can keep them private , they can destroy them , or they can rip them up , " he said .

Unlike congressional committees , members are not legally required to hold onto their office ' s files .

The State of the Union text was never " filed or deposited " with her , nor did she have " custody " of it in the legal sense .

( AP ) " Her copy of the State of the Union address is not a government record or government property at all , " Douglas Cox , professor of law at the City University of New York School of Law and an expert in the laws on the preservation of government records , told us .

Under House rules , members of Congress are encouraged to preserve their records or donate them to a research institution for historical study , Cox said .
Experts told us Pelosi ' s move was not illegal because her copy of Trump ' s speech wasn ' t the official government record that would need to be preserved .

" The State of the Union is a presidential record , which must go to the National Archives under the Presidential Records Act , " Nourse said " ( Pelosi ) did not mutilate the record that is filed with the Archives . "

Under the Electoral College system , candidates spend almost all of their general election campaign time in urban and suburban areas in 10 to 12 battleground states , Speel said .
Supporters of the Electoral College argue that keeping it requires candidates to get votes from all parts of the country , including less populated areas .
( Perhaps whoever created the Facebook post added the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico to arrive at " 43 states . " )
Background on the Electoral College process Voters on Election Day choose who they want as president , yet the final vote comes later through the Electoral College , which consists of 538 electors .
States with more people have more representatives .

Eliminating the Electoral College ( and not creating a new system in its place ) would mean that the president is elected based on the popular vote - that is , who gets the most votes on Election Day .
Opponents say that it actually makes candidates focus only on swing states - states where the margin is close enough that either party has a chance of winning .
( Though not a state , the District of Columbia is allocated three electors due to a constitutional amendment .
It could also be that candidates avoid places like Los Angeles because they are reliably Democratic and focus instead on winning swing regions , Gardner said .
" Presidential candidates are not going to campaign for the general election in rural areas no matter what system is used , simply because there are n't enough votes there , " Speel said .
In a popular vote system , they would likely stick to those regions but in a greater variety of states , he said .
But it ' s uncertain whether candidates would even make that change .
" If the Electoral College were abolished , presumably the president would be elected by nationwide majority vote , " Gardner said .
U.S. territories , like Puerto Rico , do not get electors and can not vote in the general election . )

A voter in Los Angeles County would have exactly the same input into the presidential election as would a voter in rural Wyoming if a national popular vote were used to elect the president , said Robert Speel , a political science associate professor at Penn State Erie , The Behrend College .
The post , taken literally , makes no sense , said James A. Gardner , an election law expert at the University at Buffalo School of Law .
" So maybe the author is trying inartfully to say this , " Gardner said of the Facebook post .
The post doesn ' t specify which states , nor does it make clear if it means the county will be stronger than the 43 states combined or compared to each .
The number of electors a state gets equals the combined number of members a state has in the U.S. House of Representatives and the U.S. Senate .
( The candidate who reaches 270 Electoral College votes wins . )

In a direct popular vote system , candidates might adjust their campaign strategy to appear in major media markets like Los Angeles , because that would be the most efficient use of campaign resources .
The 43 states ' collective population - about 163.7 million - is about 16 times that of Los Angeles County .

Heitkamp lost her bid for re-election in 2018 .

label: REFUTES

label: SUPPORTS
claim: Witnesses have been part of ""every other impeachment trial the Senate has ever had."""
evidences: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer , D-N.Y. , has vowed to force votes on witnesses and documents in the Republican-controlled chamber .
Democrats say avoiding witnesses would be tantamount to a cover-up .

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi , D-Calif. , delayed sending the Senate the articles of impeachment while seeking -among other things - a commitment to call witnesses from Republicans who control the Senate .
Witnesses have been a key point of debate in the lead up to President Donald Trump ' s impeachment trial before the U.S. Senate .
Let ' s break out the history books .
Senate has held 15 impeachment trials The Senate has held just two prior impeachment trials against presidents - Bill Clinton in 1999 and Andrew Johnson in 1868 .
That leaves 13 impeachment trials against other federal officials dating back to 1804 .

" I think there was a little bit of a sense - as there often is with things like Senate procedure - that the precedent is ambiguous and can be used however you want it , " Bookbinder told PolitiFact Wisconsin .
Both included witnesses .
Have witnesses really been called in every other Senate impeachment ?

" Every other impeachment trial the Senate has ever had , including those for other federal officials aside from the two presidential impeachments ... has included witnesses , " Baldwin said in a Jan. 19 , 2020 , appearance on WISN-TV ' s ' UpFront ' program .
The U.S. Senate website lists 19 people prior to Trump who were impeached by the House , including 14 judges , a senator , a Supreme Court justice and the secretary of war .
Asked for evidence of Baldwin ' s claim , her staff simply pointed to the Washington Post rundown .
Eight of those yielded a guilty verdict , and five a not-guilty finding .
... Every Senate impeachment trial that has been completed has involved witnesses . "
His group is a nonpartisan , nonprofit watchdog that seeks to promote ethics in government and reduce the influence of money in politics .
The piece said in part : " Although at least one senator has suggested that the Senate has no duty to go beyond testimony obtained by the House , that has happened on multiple occasions .
But all of them involved witnesses , said Noah Bookbinder , executive director of the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington .
Lawyers and researchers from the organization dug through Congressional archives and historical records for every impeachment for Bookbinder ' s Jan. 9 , 2020 , op-ed in the Washington Post .

Cases against three of the judges were halted before a trial when the judges resigned , and the case against Sen. William Blount in 1799 - the first impeachment in U.S. history - stopped before trial when the Senate determined it didn ' t have such jurisdiction over one of its own .
In the Clinton case , House managers obtained depositions from the witnesses and excerpts of that testimony were shown to the Senate , the Washington Post reported .
And Wisconsin ' s Democratic senator , Tammy Baldwin , said it would also be breaking with centuries of tradition .

Bookbinder ' s piece also noted three recent trials have involved witnesses not called during the House phase of the impeachment proceedings : Judge Walter Nixon in 1989 , Clinton and Judge Thomas Porteous in 2010 .

The Senate heard from seven witnesses at Walter Nixon ' s trial who had not testified before the House ; three at Clinton ' s trial who also had not testified before the House ; and 17 at Porteous ' s trial who had not testified before the House . "
" We found that it ' s not ambiguous in this case .
But those aren ' t the only impeachments the Senate has heard .
The Senate heard testimony from 41 witnesses in the Johnson proceeding , and three for Clinton , including Monica Lewinsky .

label: REFUTES

evidences: As the United States preps for the spread of the coronavirus , a conspiracy video on social media makes claims that President Donald Trump helped create the virus .
The video has been viewed around 6,000 times on a YouTube channel called " stranger than fiction news . "
( Read more about our partnership with Facebook . )
This conspiracy theory is based on speculation and contains zero evidence that Trump has anything to do with the the creation of the coronavirus .
The video was shared by STFN Reloaded , which has posted other coronavirus-related claims that we have rated False .
The video , narrated in a male voice , says " top secret documents " predict that a flu-like pandemic would strike America and kill millions of people .
Its title reads : " BREAKING : TRUMP SPAWNED WUHAN SUPER VIRUS OUTBREAK UNDER CODE NAME ' ZYPHR ' ACCORDING TO DOCUMENTS . "

There are no " documents , " or any other sort of evidence , that support the theory that Trump is behind the creation of the coronavirus , which had killed six people in the U.S. as of March 3 , 2020 .

While the narrator claims the documents are apparently going around " U.S. establishments , " there are no credible reports that reflect this information , and the video provides no links or evidence that it exists .
The video was flagged as part of Facebook ' s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed .
This is a hoax .

label: REFUTES

evidences: A spam website republished satire as genuine news in an effort to spread misinformation about former President Barack Obama and Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi .

The article said he was transferred because officials saw nothing of concern .

The Defense Department said al-Baghdadi was not in U.S. custody in 2009 .

Obama , however , was first elected president in 2008 .

King said he recalled al-Baghdadi leaving in 2009 and saying , " I ' ll see you guys in New York . "
Its headline : " ' He ' s low risk , ' said Obama before freeing ISIS leader al Baghdadi . "

When we first looked into al-Baghdadi ' s release , the Defense Department told us the future ISIS leader was held at a U.S. detention facility in Iraq known as Camp Bucca from early February 2004 until early December 2004 .

Obama wasn ' t in office when the United States had al-Baghdadi The AJUANews.com story seems to have been lifted word-for-word from a November article with the same headline on ObamaWatcher , a site that says it posts conservative satire .
A U.S.-Iraq agreement did drive the transfer of many detainees to Iraq in 2009 , but that framework was set up by President George W. Bush in 2008 .

King later told ABC News he " could be mistaken " and that al-Baghdadi ' s " face is very familiar . "
Some politicians , pundits and news outlets have inaccurately claimed Obama let al-Baghdadi go in 2009 .

There ' s no record of him being held at any other time .

He added that Soleimani deserved to be brought to justice and " supported terror and sowed chaos . "

A response from Haley ' s spokesman included such a broad interpretation of the word " mourning " to render its definition meaningless , saying Democrats are " effectively " mourning Soleimani by questioning whether the United States is better off after his killing .

Instead , she focused on criticizing Trump for his handling of policy toward Iran .

" I hope the administration has thought through the second- and third-order consequences of the paths they have chosen , " Biden wrote .
In a second tweet , she didn ' t repeat the preface criticizing Soleimani , nor did she in comments to CNN ' s Jake Tapper .
The Democratic leadership Top congressional Democrats echoed the critiques offered by the presidential candidates .
forces . "

She said in her first statement that the airstrike was " provocative and disproportionate " and in a later statement that it raised " urgent questions about the timing , manner and justification " for the operation .
Klobuchar : In her statement after the airstrike , the Minnesota senator criticized the " timing , manner , and potential consequences of the administration ' s actions . "
He said much the same in a streamed campaign event he tweeted out , briefly mentioning Soleimani but neither explicitly criticizing or praising him .

Buttigieg : In a statement , the former South Bend , Ind. , mayor said that Soleimani was a threat who " masterminded threats and attacks on Americans and our allies , leading to hundreds of deaths . "

Sanders : The Vermont senator ' s written statement had nothing positive to say about Soleimani , focusing instead on how the " assassination " by Trump was a " dangerous escalation " that " brings us closer to another disastrous war in the Middle East that could cost countless lives and trillions more dollars . "

Here are some of the statements by these Democrats : Biden : In a written statement , the former vice president said that " no American will mourn Qassem Soleimani ' s passing . "
Businessman Tom Steyer tweeted that Soleimani was " a terrorist responsible for killing Americans . "

Warren : The Massachusetts senator ' s message evolved in the days after the airstrike .
Sen. Cory Booker , D-N.J. , said on MSNBC that " Soleimani has American blood on his hands . "
In these later statements , Warren said nothing positive about Soleimani .
She went on to call Trump ' s action " reckless " and something that " escalates the situation with Iran and increases the likelihood of more deaths and new Middle East conflict . "
Buttigieg tweeted that Trump owes American troops a strategy and should give Americans answers .
But nothing she wrote could be considered an expression of " mourning . "
Buttigieg called for a deliberative approach that includes working with Congress and U.S. allies and said we must prepare for the potential of escalation .

label: REFUTES
claim: Says John F. Kennedy "smoked cannabis in the White House, while president, because he suffered from severe back pain and Addison's disease."""
evidences: Nearly 50 years later , Tommy Chong promoted his drug of choice by invoking one of Nixon ' s political rivals and predecessor as president , John F. Kennedy .
Kennedy appears to be exhaling smoke while holding perhaps a cigar of some sort .

The post features a black-and-white image of Kennedy in a shirt and tie .
Chong , an actor and part of the former Cheech and Chong comedy team , made his plug for pot with a Jan. 30 post on Instagram that has more than 70,000 likes .

Richard Nixon signed a law designating marijuana - along with ecstasy , heroin and LSD - a drug that has " no currently accepted medical use in the United States , a lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision and a high potential for abuse . "
A 1998 book on Mary Meyer , one of Kennedy ' s mistresses , recounted a 1976 National Enquirer story that said Meyer and Kennedy smoked marijuana once at the White House .
We asked historians and consulted the history books .
Kennedy suffered from a number of serious ailments , including chronic back pain and Addison ' s disease ( which causes extreme fatigue and other symptoms ) .
There ' s no proof he smoked marijuana to treat his ailments .
According to the Post , Pruitt confirmed his account about the marijuana smoking , said he had given the marijuana to Meyer , and he said the Enquirer had paid him for the story .
He served less than three years as president before being assassinated in Dallas in 1963 .
" I have n't found any evidence in either the records here or in secondary sources that the president used cannabis as a treatment for any of his medical conditions , " she told us .
We messaged Chong ' s website but didn ' t get a reply .
He was known for trying to keep them secret .
But none of that goes to the idea that Kennedy regularly used marijuana at the White House in order to fight his ailments .

Stacey Flores Chandler , a reference archivist at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library , told us the foundation has Kennedy ' s medical records from the 1950s and ' 60s as well as records of several of Kennedy 's physicians .
The Washington Post reported on the Enquirer article at the time .
The information in the article was attributed to the late Jim Pruitt , who by then was a former Washington Post editor , who said Meyer told him about the encounter .

Chandler also noted that historian Robert Dallek , who had access to Kennedy ' s medical records , wrote about amphetamines , steroids , painkillers and other medications prescribed for Kennedy ' s back and Addison ' s , but made no mention of marijuana .

label: REFUTES

evidences: The post misrepresents the Iran nuclear deal from 2015 .

But it included China , France , Germany , Russia , the United Kingdom and the European Union - not just the United States and Iran .
In January 2016 , then-Secretary of State John Kerry said he expected that some of the money ultimately would end up with organizations involved in terrorism .
The agreement was promoted by Obama .

Per the deal , the United States and other countries lifted the sanctions and the funds were unfrozen after nuclear inspectors verified in January 2016 that Iran was doing enough to curb its nuclear program .
The deal resulted in Iran getting access to some of its own funds - assets that had been frozen - it wasn ' t cash given to Iran by the United States .
( On Jan. 5 , in the aftermath of the airstrikes , Iran said it no longer will comply with limits on uranium enrichment provided under the deal . )
And $ 150 billion is a high-end estimate and the one with the least evidence to support it .
The high-end estimate from the U.S. Treasury Department in 2015 was $ 56 billion , and outside analysts believed the number could be lower .
It ' s worth noting that it was not clear what became of the unfrozen funds .

label: REFUTES
claim: "Obama ordered CIA to train ISIS Jihadists"
evidences: " Obama ordered CIA to train ISIS Jihadists , " reads the over-the-top headline .

A blog post from five years ago that claims President Barack Obama ordered the CIA to train members of ISIS continues to circulate on the internet , despite the fact that it severely mischaracterizes the intent and outcome of a CIA operation .

The program had some unintended consequences - at times , weapons intended for Syrian rebels were stolen and sold on the black market , for example - but it was never designed to " train ISIS Jihadists , " as the post claims .
In 2013 , the CIA operated a program that both trained and armed Syrian rebels in an attempt to support stronger opposition to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad .
The program , code named Timber Sycamore , was a joint effort primarily between the CIA and other Arab intelligence agencies .
" And this is exactly what the supporting powers to the opposition want , in order to isolate the Syrian Regime , which is considered the strategic depth of the Shia expansion ( Iraq and Iran ) . "

The document did not say the United States considered supporting this outcome , however .
The program and its details are still largely classified .
While the document does not say anything about Obama , it seemed to explore some of the CIA training program ' s potential effects on Iraq .
" If the situation unravels there is the possibility of establishing a declared or undeclared Salafist principality in Eastern Syria , " reads the document .
Once , stolen CIA-supplied weapons were used in a shooting in Amman , Jordan , that killed five people , including two Americans .
The training program Despite what the post ' s headline says , Obama never ordered the CIA to train members of ISIS .

The post also says that the DIA document " declared that President Barack Obama and his counterparts within the coalition considered the establishment of a Salafist organization in eastern Syria in order to further downfall of the Assad regime . "
The blog post bases its claims primarily on a once-classified Defense Intelligence Agency document obtained by Judicial Watch , a conservative legal group .

The reality is not that simple .

The declassified document The document obtained by Judicial Watch said Salafi-jihadists - fundamentalists who believe in the return to traditional Islam practices - the Muslim Brotherhood and al-Qaida in Iraq were " the major forces driving the insurgency in Syria . "
The New York Times , for example , reported that the program trained thousands of fighters and was going well until Russian military aid forced the rebels to retreat .

On top of falsely alleging that Obama ordered the CIA to intentionally train members of ISIS , the post claims the released document confirms the United States and its partners " actually facilitated the rise of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria ( ISIS ) as an effective adversary against the government of the Syrian dictator President Bashar al-Assad . "
In October 2015 , the BBC reported that American officials admitted only four or five of the program ' s trainees " had actually returned to the battle . "
